description: From Middle English kneden, from Old English cnedan, from Proto-West Germanic *knedan, from Proto-Germanic *knudaną, from Proto-Indo-European *gnet- (“to press together”).

verbs.description: knead (third-person singular simple present kneads, present participle kneading, simple past kneaded or (obsolete) knead, past participle kneaded or (archaic) kneaden or (obsolete) knodden)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To work and press into a mass, usually with the hands; especially, to work, as by repeated pressure with the knuckles, into a well mixed mass, the materials of bread, cake, etc.
examples: Knead the dough by pressing down on it with the heels of both your palms and pushing it forward to stretch it, then pulling it back toward you...

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To treat or form as if by kneading; to beat.
(intransitive, felinology) Of cats, to make an alternating pressing motion with the two front paws.
examples: Cats knead with their paws when happy, just as they kneaded when feeding from their mothers as kittens.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mix thoroughly; form into a homogeneous compound.
